historicalFigures.name: Gabriel García Márquez
historicalFigures.nativeName: Gabriel José de la Concordia García Márquez (Gabo)
historicalFigures.background: Gabriel García Márquez was a novelist, screenwriter, and journalist. He is considered one of the most significant authors of the 20th century and the master of magical realism.
keyDecisions: Accepting the Nobel Prize in Literature (1982).
Engaging in political activism (friendship with Fidel Castro).
achievements: Wrote one of the best-selling books of all time.
Put Latin American literature on the map.
historicalFigures.legacy: Gabo is the soul of Colombia. Macondo is a metaphor for Latin America.
quotes: It is not true that people stop pursuing dreams because they grow old, they grow old because they stop pursuing dreams.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His face is on the currency. He defined the country's image abroad.
primarySources: Love in the Time of Cholera.
modernInterpretations: His political views are sometimes debated.

historicalFigures.name: Simón Bolívar
historicalFigures.nativeName: Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios
historicalFigures.background: Simón Bolívar, known as 'El Libertador', was a Venezuelan military and political leader who led the independence of Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia from the Spanish Empire.
keyDecisions: Crossing the Andes to liberate New Granada (Colombia).
Dreaming of a united Gran Colombia.
achievements: The George Washington of South America.
historicalFigures.legacy: Bolívar is the father of the nation. Every town has a plaza named after him.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a semi-divine figure in South American history.
modernInterpretations: His authoritarian tendencies are acknowledged by historians.

historicalFigures.name: Policarpa Salavarrieta
historicalFigures.background: Policarpa Salavarrieta was a seamstress who spied for the Revolutionary forces during the Spanish Reconquista. She was captured and executed by the Spanish.
keyDecisions: Encouraging the people to rebel before her execution.
challenges: Being a woman in a war zone.
The Terror of the Spanish Reconquista.
historicalFigures.legacy: La Pola is the most famous heroine of Colombia. She is on the currency.
quotes: Indolent people! How different would be your fate today if you knew the price of freedom!
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: A TV series was made about her life. She is a symbol of liberty.

historicalFigures.name: Francisco de Paula Santander
historicalFigures.nativeName: Francisco José de Paula Santander y Omaña
historicalFigures.background: Francisco de Paula Santander was a military and political leader during the independence war. He served as Vice President of Gran Colombia and is known as the 'Man of the Laws'.
keyDecisions: Organizing the government while Bolívar fought.
achievements: Established the legal framework of Colombia.
historicalFigures.legacy: Santander is the father of the Colombian state. His emphasis on law over force is a core national value (in theory).
quotes: Arms have given you independence, the laws will give you freedom.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He represents the legalistic tradition of Colombia.
modernInterpretations: His rivalry with Bolívar defines the early history of the nation.

historicalFigures.name: Shakira
historicalFigures.background: Shakira is a singer, songwriter, and dancer. She is the 'Queen of Latin Music' and one of the best-selling music artists of all time.
keyDecisions: Crossing over to the English market (Laundry Service).
historicalFigures.legacy: Shakira is Colombia's greatest cultural ambassador. She put Barranquilla on the map.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is a source of immense national pride.

historicalFigures.name: Fernando Botero
historicalFigures.background: Fernando Botero was a figurative artist and sculptor. His signature style, known as 'Boterismo', depicts people and figures in large, exaggerated volume.
keyDecisions: Developing his unique style of volume.
Donating his art to museums in Bogotá and Medellín.
achievements: Most famous living artist from Latin America (during his life).
challenges: The death of his son in a car accident.
historicalFigures.legacy: Botero is the face of Colombian art. His sculptures are in major cities around the world.
quotes: I don't paint fat people. I paint volume.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: The Botero Museum is a national treasure. He is a symbol of generosity.

historicalFigures.name: Pablo Escobar
historicalFigures.background: Pablo Escobar was a drug lord and the leader of the Medellín Cartel. He was one of the wealthiest criminals in history and waged a war against the Colombian state.
keyDecisions: Ordering the bombing of Avianca Flight 203.
Surrendering to his own prison (La Catedral).
achievements: Controlled 80% of the global cocaine market.
Built housing for the poor (Robin Hood image).
Brought the state to its knees.
historicalFigures.legacy: Escobar is the dark shadow over Colombia. His legacy is violence and narcoterrorism, though some poor still revere him.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He defined the 'narco' era. 'Narcos' series popularized his story globally.
modernInterpretations: Reviled as a monster by most.
A complex figure of fascination in pop culture.

historicalFigures.name: Jorge Eliécer Gaitán
historicalFigures.background: Jorge Eliécer Gaitán was a populist leader and presidential candidate. His assassination in 1948 triggered the 'Bogotazo' riots and the period known as 'La Violencia'.
achievements: Most popular politician of his time.
historicalFigures.legacy: Gaitán is the lost hope. His death is the turning point in modern Colombian history.
quotes: I am not a man, I am a people.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His image is on the currency. The Bogotazo is a scar on the national psyche.
modernInterpretations: His potential presidency is the great 'what if'.

historicalFigures.name: Antonia Santos
historicalFigures.background: Antonia Santos was a rebel leader in the Socorro province during the independence war. She organized and funded a guerrilla group (Coromoro guerrillas).
achievements: Her guerrillas delayed the Spanish army.
historicalFigures.legacy: Antonia Santos is a key figure in the liberation campaign. Her death inspired the troops.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is honored in the Santander region.
modernInterpretations: Her contribution was crucial to the Battle of Boyacá.

historicalFigures.name: Camilo Torres
historicalFigures.background: Camilo Torres was a Catholic priest and sociologist who joined the ELN guerrilla group. He tried to reconcile Marxism and Catholicism (Liberation Theology).
keyDecisions: Founding the Sociology faculty at National University.
historicalFigures.legacy: Camilo Torres is an icon of the Latin American left. 'The duty of every Christian is to be a revolutionary.'
quotes: If Jesus were alive, he would be a guerrilla.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He inspired many to join the armed struggle.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a martyr by the left.

historicalFigures.name: Nairo Quintana
historicalFigures.background: Nairo Quintana is a professional road racing cyclist. He is one of the most successful Latin American cyclists in history, known as 'Nairoman'.
historicalFigures.legacy: Nairo is a national hero. He proved that Colombians could conquer the world's biggest races.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Cycling is the national sport because of him.

historicalFigures.name: Álvaro Uribe
historicalFigures.background: Álvaro Uribe was the President of Colombia from 2002 to 2010. He is known for his hardline stance against the FARC guerrillas (Democratic Security policy).
keyDecisions: Amending the constitution to run for re-election.
achievements: Most popular president in history (at the time).
historicalFigures.legacy: Uribe is the most polarizing figure in modern Colombia. To some, a savior; to others, a warmonger.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Uribismo is a major political force.

historicalFigures.name: Juan Manuel Santos
historicalFigures.background: Juan Manuel Santos was the President of Colombia from 2010 to 2018. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating a peace treaty with the FARC.
keyDecisions: Initiating peace talks with the FARC.
achievements: Ended the 50-year war with the FARC.
challenges: The 'No' vote in the peace referendum.
historicalFigures.legacy: Santos is the peacemaker. He achieved the impossible, though the peace is fragile.
quotes: Peace is much more difficult than war.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His legacy is tied to the success of the peace process.

historicalFigures.name: Rafael Núñez
historicalFigures.background: Rafael Núñez was a four-time President and the author of the national anthem. He led the 'Regeneration' movement and wrote the 1886 Constitution which lasted until 1991.
keyDecisions: Restoring the power of the Catholic Church.
Writing the lyrics to the National Anthem.
achievements: Created the modern Colombian state structure.
historicalFigures.legacy: Núñez is the architect of the conservative republic. His constitution ruled for 100 years.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Every Colombian sings his words in the anthem.
modernInterpretations: His centralism is blamed for regional underdevelopment.

historicalFigures.name: Sofía Vergara
historicalFigures.background: Sofía Vergara is an actress and model. She became the highest-paid actress in American television for her role in 'Modern Family'.
challenges: The murder of her brother in Colombia.
historicalFigures.legacy: Sofía is a crossover success story. She opened doors for Latinas in US comedy.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is one of the most recognizable faces in the world.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated for her humor and business acumen.

historicalFigures.name: James Rodríguez
historicalFigures.background: James Rodríguez is a professional footballer. He won the Golden Boot at the 2014 World Cup and is considered one of the best Colombian players ever.
keyDecisions: Leading Colombia to the quarterfinals in 2014.
Scoring the goal against Uruguay (Puskas Award).
historicalFigures.legacy: James is the golden boy. His 2014 performance is the high point of Colombian football history.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is an idol to millions.
modernInterpretations: His career trajectory is a topic of debate.

historicalFigures.name: Manuel Elkin Patarroyo
historicalFigures.background: Dr. Manuel Elkin Patarroyo is a pathologist and immunologist. He developed the first synthetic vaccine against malaria (SPf66).
keyDecisions: Donating the patent to the WHO.
challenges: Controversy over the use of monkeys in research.
historicalFigures.legacy: Patarroyo is Colombia's most famous scientist. He proved that developing countries could do cutting-edge science.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He inspired a generation of scientists.
modernInterpretations: His vaccine's failure to be a silver bullet is acknowledged.

historicalFigures.name: Totó la Momposina
historicalFigures.background: Totó la Momposina is a singer of traditional music from the Caribbean coast. She is the queen of Cumbia and Bullerengue, preserving the Afro-Indigenous roots of Colombian music.
keyDecisions: Performing at the Nobel Prize ceremony for Garcia Marquez.
Touring the world with traditional music.
challenges: Lack of commercial support for folklore.
historicalFigures.legacy: Totó is the voice of the ancestors. She kept the folklore alive.
quotes: Music is the identity of a people.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a matriarch of music.
